body:
@adriancole I think it's a great idea! The possibility to let non native programmers edit the documentation and be sure it's still valid is the win of using Dredd. 

The idea behind Dredd is be able abstract the discussion about the HTTP API to the lingua franca contract - the API Blueprint, but keep it tightly bound to the implementation with [hooks](https://dredd.readthedocs.org/en/latest/hooks/) and tested in CI (!), so it won't get out of sync.

I think the only catch in your case can be Dredd doesn't support Scala or Java at this moment. But it has precedent support for compiled language ([Go](http://dredd.readthedocs.org/en/latest/hooks-go/)) and [tutorial support for adding new language](https://dredd.readthedocs.org/en/latest/hooks-new-language/) including the [language agnostic testing harness](https://github.com/apiaryio/dredd-hooks-template) so it shouldn't be a problem to add your's if needed. 

I'm excited to help with anything. Just ping me here, on twitter (@ntmlk) or we can schedule a little call if needed.

@yurishkuro That's great, I'll reach out when we get down to it to make sure we converge the APIs. django-zipkin has call site instrumentation, documented at https://github.com/prezi/django-zipkin#recording-annotations.

@adriancole  I just had a look at the API Blueprint document in #888. I don't know how does the entire API looks like but it API seems to be quite simple to eme. If it has only `GET` methods you could probably seed it with some script before Dredd execution and any sophisticated isolation of each action with hooks shouldn't be necessary.

PS it is totally my goal to re-use whatever framework we make for a v2 api.
I'm using v1 as it is the only thing we have implemented, and what all the
current tracers are built on.
cc @yurishkuro

I think `api-docs` tool should not be coupled with `e2e testing` tool. api-docs tool should be judged on its expressionability. A decent enough e2e testing framework should be easily plugged in with any of the api-docs tools or can be also tested directly with endpoints (not sure how api-docs help there).

I haven't have an experience with `blueprint` so can't comment much. But i would say, a feature to explore APIs and test them directly (like [here](http://petstore.swagger.io/)) comes handy a lot of times.

first step: https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/pull/890/files

once in, we can give a go at bower (except for the dagre-d3-legacy thing)
are we ok on no-op here?
Thanks!

@liyichao wrt "why the graph initially collapsed" the collapsed-ness has to do with the serviceName query. For example, if the serviceName parameter corresponds to the root span, it will show up collapsed. If it doesn't it will expand to the child that contains it. Feel free to spin off another issue on this if you feel that behavior isn't ideal cc @yurishkuro

wrt your original concern (about end time resetting) I see that this is certainly the case.

For example, if you start from scratch, ex. where there's no query params in the URL, you can select any time, and the page will return with the correct endTs query parameter.

If you already have an endTs query parameter, changing the endtime date or time fields has no effect.

The work around is to clear the URL when you want to change. I agree this is a bug.
Does this approach only work in deployments with a single collector process, i.e. it's not scalable to multiple collectors?

> Does this approach only work in deployments with a single collector
> process, i.e. it's not scalable to multiple collectors?

I presume your question is about the adaptive sampler module in general,
since this change doesn't impact the topic.

The adaptive sampler works on multiple collectors as a leader is elected to
manage updates to the sampleRate based on the storeRate of each member. Ex.
There is code to review store rates under a zookeeper path and then
calculate what the sample rate should be.

Next step is to add a test that proves this actually works ;) that said,
this code is used at Twitter with a dozen collector instances (or was half
a year ago), so I suspect it does.
releasing as 1.28.0

That's the way it is supposed to be. Then, you can generate thrift files yourself. I think zipkin-scrooge is a package that contains auto-generated code.

The tab is called dependencies and there will only be data if you are
running MySQL or Cassandra with the zipkin-dependencies-spark job.

I followed the example at DZone (https://dzone.com/articles/knowing-how-all-your) and ended up with a UI thats very different than the screenshots posted on the blog. 

For me, no Timeline tab, Dependencies appearing on the top menu, no service summary, stats box, favorites etc. Sort of limited UI functionality overall. Not sure if I am running a different version of zipkin-web.

Tried the tracegen to generate some data but still nothing to the effect. Does it mean that DB backend is required for the UI to be fully featured?

That dzone article is almost 2 years old and doesn't serve as
documentation. The project has been rehosted to OpenZipkin and the UI
changed before that happened. The hadoop code to produce an aggregate view
was not merged when that article was written either. Long story short: we
can't change the past, so if your goal is to get started, why no engage
with us in the present?

As mentioned in the last thread, the MySQL storage type does query-time
aggregating, which isn't that scalable, but does work for small data sets.

I have no idea which data store you are using, but assuming it is
Cassandra, you can use the spark job (as we no longer support hadoop)

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin-dependencies-spark

If you'd like to discuss more, you can join
https://gitter.im/openzipkin/zipkin
Thanks for the clarification. We plan to use MySQL. Will try it out. Appreciate your help on this.
anytime!

Good idea. I suppose  this is the difference  between unknown  and not know
yet. Make sure the update also updates the thrift which says empty string
is not allowed.

Hi, yuri. I'm in favor of this (ex making the de-facto label "unknown" something a user or instrumentation must opt into).

The changes you reverted were added for consistency, particularly to ensure that we don't end up with data that isn't queryable. In your experience, you've found it better to make "" unqueryable, which I can certainly see the logic in (basically this is effectively making this field optional)

Can you add a summary here about the semantics of empty string? I know there are places in docs where we say empty is prohibited, so please do a quick sweep of serviceName accessors to ensure this change doesn't end up confusing ppl

https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/blob/master/zipkin-thrift/src/main/thrift/com/twitter/zipkin/zipkinCore.thrift#L179

Alternatively (and because this is in my timezone, and a branch on the main repo), I can make these changes and fold them into this. I expect my suggestions to be documentation affecting only (maybe another test, but yeah).

wdyt?

I replaced the references to "unknown" with "" in `zipkinCore.thrift`.

FWIW, we've been sending empty strings as service name without any ill effects, the only exception being the UI issue #896. And I recall seeing somewhere, maybe in the old Hadoop job, a code that was checking for empty strings.

Thought a lot about this recently.. I think it is best to just leave off Closeable from the interfaces completely. This defers how to express close-ability to the implementing types, which might choose to be java closeable or twitter closeable or something else. Why use slash as a separator instead of dot?
- for those accustomed to urls and xpaths, having slash in the middle but not at the front looks weird
- in informal written English slash is often used to mean "or", as in "If/when Mary ever shows up"
- slash needs to be encoded when passed in http query string `http%2Fpath`, dot doesn't
The issue was introduced in 2412c4b8, Groovy doesn't interpolate on `'`, only on `"`. PR coming up.

Slashes were used in the common model doc, which a lot of this came out of,
so that is how it started. Slashes fit nicely with URNs, for example, as a
relative path. Ex google cloud trace keys are exactly the same as these,
but have a different implied URN namespace.

I didn't hear any resistance to slash encoding on the distributed-tracing
thread that led to this, nor from Jordi, Kristof or others that saw the
preperatory pull request. Maybe they weren't considering the URL encoding
aspect, or not considering it as a major concern. We should find out it if
is widely shared before merging.

Specifically about URL encoding. You are right that this implies encoding
the slashes. That said, you'll notice though the query format of zipkin v1
already requires this due to " and " syntax. I didn't consider this a
driving factor and was hoping to be more common to be others on these keys.
I didn't enumerate this tradeoff eventhough I thought about it. Thanks for
bringing it up.

Anyone else have an opinion about this?

Ex in google cloud trace

"http/status_code" is implicitly
 "trace.cloud.google.com/http/status_code" and you can use either in their
system.
Good eye!
Awesome turnaround! Will cut a new release shortly
@CodingFabian FYI, I have a WIP for the changes in brave, and in case I don't raise that before I fly out.

i don't have any strong opinions on the name. Though i am curious if these binary annotations (http/path, http/staus_code) will have special behaviour in the zipkin system? in other words, if my tracer still pushes `http.uri`, will it lose something? (other than being different from java/scala tracers).

There's no impact. Your tracer can store "mary had a little lamb" if it
wanted to :P

These are suggested labels, with a goal that folks want to use them. For
example, if these are logged commonly (eventually), users don't need to
remember different rules per language or framework. In many cases, there's
only one or two frameworks, this is more valuable when there are several
different tracers contributing to the same system.
right. i missed the point about different tracers contributing to the same system.

I haven't heard anyone voice an opinion in favor of the slash delimited syntax. There have been two questions about the former syntax, and one request to retain it. The URN thing is contrived, as we don't have any requirement to support this. I'll see if I can smoke out any strong opinion for slashes, and if not, switch to dots.

I think summary in favor of '/' is that it is probably a better delimiter in isolation. However, this isn't truly green field. There's prior art in zipkin using dots. Plus, "http/path=/foo/bar" indeed looks worse than "http.path=/foo/bar", regardless of URL encoding.

Long story short.. will change to dots.

OK I switched the convention to dots.

I also added "http.response.size" and "http.request.size", convention borrowed from google cloud trace (except dots not slashes).

While not widely supported in existing tracers, http size is widely supported in log-based analysis, including [common logfile format](https://www.w3.org/Daemon/User/Config/Logging.html#common-logfile-format) (which is over 20years old at this point). It would be nice to show folks how to use zipkin instead.

Any opinions? @yurishkuro @kristofa @jcarres-mdsol @prat0318
I like it.

Seconding this request, needing to update the sort dropdown every time after querying for new traces is a bit inconvenient.

Zipkin is definitely one of my favorite projects to watch :)
thanks

I do not think it is necessary.
You can get all unique services by sr/ss from the store compare them with unique by ca and there you have your stats.

made a comment in the PR. I think the flooring concern shouldn't be conflated with the "today" one.

cassandra's impl will take an input date and floor it to a day. So, they can be retrieved, subject to the window which is a documented aspect of the dependency api. If the tests don't show that working, we can adjust them.

What I'm concerned about is losing a test that shows we can process data older than a day. For example, if _all_ of our tests look at _today_, we can easily make an impl that cannot process, for example, the data from 2 days ago. After looking at the test in question, I can tell that this aspect is non-obvious.

The test data should be explicitly a relative date such as 2 or 3 days ago (which avoids problems around any lookback defaults), as opposed to constants (which it has now). Also, we can rename the test to something like lookback3days which is doubley calls out the nature of the concern.

@jcarres-mdsol to be clear, you are suggesting that the concern of reporting uninstrumented edges can be addressed in a different manner. Ex that the dependency graph doesn't need to hold this concern?

sorry, replied on PR before seeing this. If the primary concern was "test that shows we can process data older than a day", then the fix is simple - I can probably leave the trace timestamps the same, but only change the query time to "today", because it's how Cassandra job always stores the result.

Just to clarify what I want to do. I think of Dependency Graph as representing the architecture of the system, showing which services talk to each other. That function should be independent of how different tracers report data on RPC spans - one span or two spans. But at least in the Cassandra Spark job it is implemented to only build a link between two services if their names come from _two distinct spans_. I want to change that, and allow the job to consider, for example, standalone spans where the other service is still known (from SA or CA), as that still represents a valid architectural link.

As an illustration, look at the issue https://github.com/openzipkin/zipkin/issues/917. For a human it is obvious that there are 3 services involved in that "headless" trace, but the test expects only one link in the output.

So that's the primary objective of this ticket. The enum field is just a bit of extra data to record in each link, since the job now knows which of the two services was actually sending spans that were responsible for the link.

@jcarres-mdsol I am not quite following your suggestion. There is no way to query Cassandra in bulk, a M/R job is the only way to process all the data.  Per above, all the information is already present during the main Spark job, so the recording that information in the link seems like the best approach.

@t-yuki enhancing the interface is great! Only it's not clear to me what "take back" button means. Should it be just called "Run" or "Query" or "Execute"?
ok, LGTM

@adriancole I've restored the odd timestamps, as they don't affect how the test runs in the Spark job. The main fix is to make the query as-of today, else it doesn't find the dependencies data stored in Cassandra.

@adriancole @jcarres-mdsol I've updated the description with the actual two new tests I am using to test the behavior. So far they only account for the shape of the graph, not for the extra enum describing the edge origin.

Why wouldn't the fix be to have the spark job store the data with
timestamps according to the spans? It seems like you are saying the data is
timestamped for when it was processed, which doesn't make sense at all.

Ex. here's the parameter.. it is clearly about the timestamps of the
spans, not the time the job happened to run
- @param endTs only return links from spans where
  [[com.twitter.zipkin.common.Span.timestamp]]
-              are at or before this time in epoch milliseconds.

serveraddress was added to allow far-right resources to show up, for example, uninstrumented mysql servers, S3, etc.

clientaddress was not as it explodes the far left

I changed the label to "Analyze Dependencies".
Also I added a missing file.
PTAL.

@adriancole by far-right do you mean those that will not log their own annotations? In that case the span will have Client Send/Recv and a ServerAddress, and the latter will win. I am not proposing to change that, only to let Server Send/Recv win over ServerAddress.

I don't have a strong opinion about who should win "sa" vs "sr", as long as
"sr" isn't required.

Would be nicer if we could resolve at collection time, but anyway..

I don't have a problem with changing the precedence, I would just make a
comment in the test with your rationale.

Seems this is an assumption that clients are more likely to make mistakes
naming the destination than servers naming themselves.. I buy that.

Yeah I think you understand my concern, which was about a potential
explosion on the left side if we named nodes based on clients (fear which
might not be substantiated).

Regardless, you've clarified to me this isn't impacted at all.

Can you paste another image?

So the endTs and lookback is the same concept here as in the span query (main screen). Can you verify the fields are named the same and look similar? (for continuity's sake across the screens). Hard to tell, and they may already be.

I'm quite excited as I was interested in being able to see dependencies from a period besides yesterday.

I wouldn't necessarily say "analyze dependencies" as not all stores will do that online, but it is a minor point and I don't know a better word either!

@jcarres-mdsol @eirslett @kristofa any thoughts?

It queries to /dependency?endTs=1234&startTs but no effect for server side.
Instead, dependency.js converts `startTs` to `lookback` and sends a query with that parameter.
However, error cases like startTs > endTs is not handled well. (it ignores `startTs` simply)

I have no idea for wording of the button. Find traces page has `Find Traces` so I write `Analyze Dependencies` in Dependencies page. Also `Query` is nice.
